image.altText: Bald man in dark blue suit walking

items.synopsis: Charlie Teo was fighting two complaints of unprofessional conduct from the families of two different women, who say they were not properly warned about the risk of death before consenting to surgery.

title.children: Neurosurgeon Charlie Teo found guilty of unsatisfactory professional conduct

image.altText: An older man with greying light hair and glasses wearing a suit and tie stands in front of a blue Reserve Bank of Australia wall

items.synopsis: RBA governor Philip Lowe is speaking in Brisbane where he's expected to discuss changes to the bank's structure and reasons for pausing its current rate hiking cycle last week. Follow live.

title.children: RBA governor reveals changes to bank's structure and reasons for rate pause

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Lowe says it's all about having more time to really digest issues in detail: The less frequent and longer meetings will provide more time for the Board to examine issues in detail and to have deeper discussions on monetary policy strategy, alternative policy options and risks, as well as on communication. Likewise, the staff will have more time for analysis, with less time spent preparing summaries of recent developments. The Board will also be able to hear directly from more staff and have greater opportunity to request work on particular topics. And the post-meeting media conferences will provide a timely opportunity to explain the Board’s decisions and to answer questions. This will complement our existing communications, including through speeches with Q & A. Together, this is a significant package of reform that will contribute to better decision-making and communication.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why hold longer meetings to decide on interest rates?

children.content: Lowe says it's all about having more time to really digest issues in detail:

The less frequent and longer meetings will provide more time for the Board to examine issues in detail and to have deeper discussions on monetary policy strategy, alternative policy options and risks, as well as on communication.
Likewise, the staff will have more time for analysis, with less time spent preparing summaries of recent developments.
The Board will also be able to hear directly from more staff and have greater opportunity to request work on particular topics.
And the post-meeting media conferences will provide a timely opportunity to explain the Board’s decisions and to answer questions.
This will complement our existing communications, including
through speeches with Q
A.
Together, this is a significant package of reform that will contribute to better decision-making and communication.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here are the other five changes that will come into effect at the RBA, as outlined by Philip Lowe: The quarterly Statement on Monetary Policy will be released at the same time as the outcome of the Board meeting (in February, May, August and November), rather than on the following Friday as is currently the case. Given this and other changes, we are reviewing the structure of this document. The Board, rather than just the Governor, will be the signatory to the Statement on the Conduct of Monetary Policy, which is the document that records the common understanding on monetary policy between the RBA and the Australian Government. The new Statement is expected to be finalised later this year. The Board will oversee the Bank’s research agenda as it relates to monetary policy and aspects of financial stability. The Bank will continue with its current approach to climate change analysis, focusing on the implications of climate change for the economy, inflation and the financial system. The Board will work with the Treasury to undertake five-yearly open and transparent reviews of the monetary policy framework.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The other changes coming to the RBA in wake of the review

children.content: Here are the other five changes that will come into effect at the RBA, as outlined by Philip Lowe:

The quarterly Statement on Monetary Policy will be released at the same time as the outcome of the Board meeting (in February, May, August and November), rather than on the following Friday as is currently the case. Given this and other changes, we are reviewing the structure of this document.

The Board, rather than just the Governor, will be the signatory to the Statement on the Conduct of Monetary Policy, which is the document that records the common understanding on monetary policy between the RBA and the Australian Government. The new Statement is expected to be finalised later this year.
The Board will oversee the Bank’s research agenda as it relates to monetary policy and aspects of financial stability.
The Bank will continue with its current approach to climate change analysis, focusing on the implications of climate change for the economy, inflation and the financial system.
The Board will work with the Treasury to undertake five-yearly open and transparent reviews of the monetary policy framework.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: RBA governor Philip Lowe is outlining 10 major changes to the bank's monetary policy processes, in the wake of the RBA review that was released a few months ago. Here's a quick rundown of the first five: RBA board will meet eight times a year instead of 11. Four of those meetings will be held on the first Tuesday of February, May, August and November, with the other four held midway between those. Board meetings will be longer, and will start on the Monday afternoon, continue on Tuesday morning, and announce the decision on 2:30pm. All Board members will be able to attend an internal staff meeting before the meeting to discuss items with a broader range of staff The post meeting statement will be issued by the Board, not the Governor, as is currently the case. The governor will hold a media conference explaining the decision an hour after announcing the decision at 3:30pm.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Reserve Bank to reduce number of meetings from 2024

children.content: RBA governor Philip Lowe is outlining 10 major changes to the bank's monetary policy processes, in the wake of the RBA review that was released a few months ago.
Here's a quick rundown of the first five:
RBA board will meet eight times a year instead of 11. Four of those meetings will be held on the first Tuesday of February, May, August and November, with the other four held midway between those.
Board meetings will be longer, and will start on the Monday afternoon, continue on Tuesday morning, and announce the decision on 2:30pm.
All Board members will be able to attend an internal staff meeting before the meeting to discuss items with a broader range of staff
The post meeting statement will be issued by the Board, not the Governor, as is currently the case.
The governor will hold a media conference explaining the decision an hour after announcing the decision at 3:30pm.

image.altText: The side of a white whale in water

items.synopsis: Researcher John Totterdell says he has never seen a "100 per cent" all-white humpback whale like the calf spotted by several groups at Ningaloo Reef off WA's north-west coast on Tuesday.

title.children: Is this Ningaloo's Migaloo? White humpback whale calf sighted in Western Australia

image.altText: shot of lake from above

items.synopsis: A small lake near the Canada-US border has been chosen as the site that may define the start of a new geological epoch called the Anthropocene.

title.children: A 'golden spike' in Canada could mark the beginning of the Anthropocene Epoch

image.altText: Erica Vlasic in her living room.

items.synopsis: Erika Vlasic received two reports about a home she wanted to buy. She said one came back with "no big issues", the other found the property was suited to "demolition".

title.children: When Erika offered $700k for a home, she didn't know it was 'better suited to demolition'

image.altText: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, center, arrives for an event on the sidelines of a NATO summit.

image.altText: medvedev sits at a table in front of a microphone with the russian flag behind him

title.children: Medvedev claims NATO's 'dead end' in Ukraine help brings World War III 'closer'

image.altText: A keep out sign on a fence

items.synopsis: As repairs slowly begin, residents still don't know when they will be able to return to their flood-ravaged homes.

title.children: Six months on from WA's worst floods, the scars are still raw in Fitzroy Crossing

image.altText: Bryan Brown sits in the crowd.

items.synopsis: Australian actor Bryan Brown is addressing the National Press Club in Canberra - follow live.

title.children: Actor Bryan Brown addresses the National Press Club

image.altText: Australia's first weatherman Alan Wilkie reads the weather in 1976 on 7 News

items.synopsis: Alan Wilkie read the weather from the ABC's first week of television broadcasts in 1956 until he left the organisation in 1960.

title.children: 'The most unlikely TV star': Australia's first on-screen weatherman, Alan Wilkie, dies aged 94

image.altText: An illustration of two women, one with her hand on the other's shoulder, in front of a stained glass window.

items.synopsis: While Jenny was trying hard to be a good Christian, she was hiding a secret shame — one that can be traced back to biblical times.

title.children: How Christianity has been weaponised by weight loss movements

image.altText: F1 driver Daniel Ricciardo celebrates by spraying champagne while standing on a podium, after winning a race.

items.synopsis: F1 is a cut-throat sport that wants immediate success. Daniel Ricciardo could be winning races again but he has to show speed in a slower car, writes Michael Doyle.

title.children: Ricciardo is back and F1 is in high spirits, but if he doesn't show pace immediately he could be out again

image.altText: A young white woman with glasses sits at a desk in front of a laptop.

items.synopsis: Australians targeted by the illegal robodebt income averaging scheme are considering their legal options after the damning royal commission report suggested there was evidence to support a further civil case.

title.children: Robodebt report provides avenue for further civil action and compensation for victims

image.altText: Elina Svitolina crouches down and covers her mouth on Wimbledon's Centre Court

items.synopsis: Elina Svitolina tells the world she will celebrate one of the biggest wins of her career with a beer as she returns to the semis of Wimbledon eight months after giving birth.

title.children: Tennis's comeback queen stuns world number one Iga Swiatek to be one match from Wimbledon final

image.altText: The walls of a youth detention centre through a barbed wire fence. A sign partially obscured by grass says 'no entry'.

items.synopsis: The Supreme Court of Western Australia finds three young detainees were subjected to "solitary confinement on a frequent basis" and were unlawfully locked in their cells at Banksia Hill Detention Centre and Unit 18 for prolonged periods.

title.children: 'Systemic failure': WA youth detainees 'unlawfully confined' during lockdowns, court finds

image.altText: Ben O'Connor strains while riding during the Tour de France

items.synopsis: Australian Ben O'Connor takes third place in the 10th stage of the Tour de France, days after illness looked to have thwarted his overall race hopes.

title.children: 'Liberated' O'Connor claims podium finish as West Aussie hopes to make late TDF splash

image.altText: Fish swim in and out of holes in the base of a sunken statue.

items.synopsis: Thirteen statues have been sunk around the end of Busselton's 1.8-kilometre-long jetty — and they're already playing home to plenty of underwater life.

title.children: Artworks become artificial reef off Busselton jetty

image.altText: ce patterns settle on a car roof in Donnybrook, Western Australia

items.synopsis: If you live in a frost-prone region you are likely familiar with the mosaic-like branches and spirals that stretch across windows and cars on an ice-cold morning. But how does Mother Nature create the magnificent display?

title.children: This isn't art. It's ice, sculpted by Mother Nature

image.altText: An elderly Indigenous man looks at the camera

items.synopsis: Ned Hargraves says many in his remote desert community still do not understand what they will be voting for, and is calling for the Voice referendum to be postponed so people have to chance to understand it.

title.children: Warlpiri elder will be voting against the Voice in the upcoming referendum. Here's why

image.altText: Man wearing navy uniform

items.synopsis: The Russian military official was shot dead by an unknown assassin while on his morning run after appearing on a Ukrainian blacklist website.

title.children: 'Liquidated': Russian commander on Ukraine's blacklist shot dead on run

image.altText: Russia U.N. Ambassador Vassily Nebenzia with his hand raised to veto extension

items.synopsis: A long-running humanitarian program delivering aid to 4 million people in Syria could be closed as Russia fights against its extension at the UN.

image.altText: Christine Rakic

items.synopsis: The body of Christine Rakic was found in her Rooty Hill home last night while her estranged husband was discovered at the scene with injuries to his throat and arms.

image.altText: A man is arrested by police from Strike Force Raptor over an alleged $26m tax fraud scheme.

image.altText: Ava the dog is standing attentively on a rug and sniffing Donna's head, while Donna hugs Ava and laughs.

image.altText: Croc hunting

image.altText: A woman walks pass shopping mall

image.altText: Stuart Dew looks downwards

image.altText: A harvester cuts through cane field while a tractor loaded with a hauling bin drives alongside to collect the harvested cane.

image.altText: Aretha Franklin sings into a microphone
